headline.main: Afghan Art Dispersed by The Winds Of War; A Nation Loses Its Heritage To Smugglers and Dealers

lead_paragraph: On a recent visit to a London antique dealer, David Kamansky, director of the Pacific Asia Museum in Pasadena, Calif., was presented with a shoe box. Inside, covered with flimsy paper, were fragments of a 2,000-year-old ivory casket, decorated with intricate Indian carvings, unmistakably part of the famous Begram collection that once belonged to the Kabul Museum in Afghanistan. ''For someone like me, it was like being handed the 'Mona Lisa' in bits,'' Mr. Kamansky said. ''Here were some of the great treasures of mankind in a shoe box, wrapped in toilet paper.''
abstract: Fabulous art treasures of Afghanistan from Greek, Buddhist and Islamic civilizations were presumed gone, destroyed by 20 years of war, economic desperation and, most recently, by Taliban's fundamentalist brand of Islam; but during last decade, much of art has made its way out of Afghanistan to North America, Western Europe and Japan; it has been found in places at end of road for smuggling; pieces have been plundered by warring factions in Afghanistan, passed into Pakistan or former Soviet lands to north, and made their way onto international art market; photos (M)
